conversation.content: [frantic] Officer, please, I know I was speeding but my mom's at Regional Medical and they just called saying she's—she doesn't have much time left and I need to get there.
[wearily] License and registration. You were doing eighty-seven in a fifty-five zone, that's reckless endangerment territory, not just a simple ticket. [exhales]
Here, take them, write whatever you need to write, but please make it fast because every minute we're standing here is a minute I might not get to say goodbye.
[distracted] Wait, you're the Chen kid, aren't you? My daughter Sarah talks about you constantly, how you're always beating her for valedictorian, how you got into MIT early admission.
[desperately] Does that matter right now?

No, I suppose it doesn't. [sighs] Look, I've been on shift for sixteen hours straight, answered three fatal accident calls tonight alone, all of them speed-related, all of them kids your age who thought they had somewhere important to be.
[voice breaking] This isn't about being late to some party or trying to impress someone, this is my mother dying, and if you're going to arrest me then just do it already.

[softer] Regional Medical's emergency entrance is under construction, you'll want to use the north parking structure instead. [pause] I lost my dad two years ago, sat in traffic for forty minutes while he died alone.
I'm sorry, I didn't know Sarah's grandfather had—I mean, she never mentioned it in any of our study groups or competitions or anything.

[thoughtfully] She doesn't talk about real things much, just grades and achievements and beating you for that valedictorian spot, like any of it actually matters when you're standing in a hospital room watching monitors flatline.
Maybe that's how she processes it, throwing herself into something she can control when everything else feels like it's falling apart around her.
Is that what you do too? [exhales] All those perfect scores and extracurriculars, building this fortress of accomplishments while your mom was getting sicker?
[quietly] The doctors said she had five years when they first diagnosed her, then it became two, then six months, and now we're down to hours apparently.
Follow me, I'll escort you there with lights. We can make it in eight minutes if we skip the usual route and cut through the industrial district. [tired laugh]
[confused] You're not giving me a ticket? After that whole speech about fatal accidents and kids thinking they're invincible?
[exhaustedly] Kid, I've written seventeen tickets tonight, sent two teenagers to jail, and I'm too tired to add making you miss your mother's last moments to my list of regrets.
[gratefully] Thank you, I mean it, and I'll tell Sarah her dad's a good person, even if she already knows that somewhere under all her stress about college applications.
Just follow my lights and keep it under seventy. [pause] And maybe after all this settles, you and Sarah could have an actual conversation instead of just competing over who memorized more formulas.
[starting to move] She's brilliant, you know, probably smarter than me in the ways that actually matter, the human ways that can't be measured by standardized tests.
Drive safe, Chen. Your mother's waiting, and despite everything I've seen tonight, I still believe in kids like you making it where you need to go. [wearily hopeful]

scenario: A police officer pulls over a star student for speeding to the hospital where their mother is dying, recognizing them as their own child's academic rival.
